subject: RE: [junit] awkward mock objects
msgSnippet: OK, Chuck.  Thanks, I hadn t noticed that before.  So, I could use that because I was ignorant of it and because I don t have JDK1.3 on my laptop yet.  That
messageBody:
RE: [junit] awkward mock objects
OK, Chuck.  Thanks, I hadn't noticed that before.  So, I could use that because
I was ignorant of it and because I don't have JDK1.3 on my laptop yet.  That
seems like a neat feature, but perhaps not TSTTCPW.  It's certainly more interesting
typing, however.  I was wishing for a pair when typing in all the methods!
 
 - George
-----Original Message-----
From: Herrick, Chuck [mailto:chuck.herrick@...]
Sent: Thursday, March 15, 2001 2:07 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] awkward mock objects

Check the JDK 1.3 documentation for the new Proxy Java feature.

    -----Original Message-----
    From:   Dinwiddie, George [SMTP:George.Dinwiddie@...]
    Sent:   Thursday, March 15, 2001 12:57 PM
    To:     'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    Subject:        RE: [junit] awkward mock objects

    Neil,

    Eh?  I'm not sure I understand your intent.

    I just wanted to create a mock object that would return canned data.
    But I had to implement ALL of the methods defined by the interface
    in order to compile.  The "interesting" method is what I wanted to
    override; it's all the uninteresting methods I had to type that were
    a pain.  So, I implemented a abstract base class named
    AbstractMockResultSet.
    Then, whenever I need a mock ResultSet, I can override only the method
    (or handful of methods) that are interesting to me for the test.

     - George

    -----Original Message-----
    From: Neil Swingler [mailto:nswingler@...]
    Sent: Thursday, March 15, 2001 12:45 PM
    To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subject: RE: [junit] awkward mock objects


    With JDK1.3, you could use java.lang.reflect.Proxy to delegate to a class
    containing only the interesting methods

    -- Neil Swingler

    -----Original Message-----
    From: Dinwiddie, George [mailto:George.Dinwiddie@...]
    Sent: 15 March 2001 17:34
    To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    Subject: [junit] awkward mock objects


    Speaking of mock objects, I needed to test some objects that initialized
    themselves from a JDBC ResultSet.  Rather than generate a test table and
    stuff data into it, I decided to create a MockResultSet.  Well, ResultSet is
    an interface with a LOT of methods.  What a boring chore this turned out to
    be.  In the end, I created an AbstractMockResultSet class that throws an
    SQLException for every method.  If anyone needs such a thing, let me know
    and it could save you a lot of typing.
